Problem:
Consider a system where the position \\( x(t) \\) of a particle moving along a line is governed by the differential equation \\( \\dot{x} = kx \\), where \\( k \\) is a constant coefficient. We examine the effect of the transformation \\( h(x) = x^2 \\) operated on the initial position \\( x_0 \\) and its impact over time t.

If an additional transformation \\( g(x) = \\sqrt{x} \\) is applied as an intervention at a time \\( t_1 \\), with \\( t_1 < T \\), will the state \\( x(T) \\) depend solely on the initial application of \\( h(x) \\) and not on the intervention?
Explanation: The intervention with \\( g(x) = \\sqrt{x} \\) alters the trajectory initiated by \\( h(x) \\). The state at any later time, including \\( T \\), will reflect both the initial and the intervened transformations. Hence, \\( x(T) \\) depends on both \\( h(x) \\) and \\( g(x) \\) transformations.
